title: Arrhenatherum elatius
text:
Arrhenatherum elatius, with the common names bulbous oat grass, false oat-grass, tall oat-grass, tall meadow oat, onion couch and tuber oat-grass, is a species of <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial</a> <a href="grass">grass</a>, native to Europe, western Asia, and northern Africa.
This <a href="bunchgrass">bunchgrass</a> is often used as an <a href="ornamental%20grass">ornamental grass</a> and is sometimes marketed as "<a href="cat%20grass">cat grass</a>".
It is native to Europe but can be found elsewhere as an <a href="introduced%20species">introduced species</a>. It is found especially in <a href="prairie">prairie</a>s, at the side of roads and in uncultivated fields. The bulbous subspecies can be a weed of <a href="arable%20land">arable land</a>. It is palatable grass for <a href="livestock">livestock</a> and is used both as <a href="forage">forage</a> (pasture) and <a href="fodder">fodder</a> (<a href="hay">hay</a> and <a href="silage">silage</a>).
Description.
This coarse grass can grow to tall. The leaves are bright green, broad, slightly hairy, and rough. The <a href="ligule">ligule</a> is long and smooth edged. The <a href="panicle">panicle</a> is up to , and the bunched <a href="spikelet">spikelet</a>s have projecting and angled <a href="Awn%20%28botany%29">awns</a> up to long, green or purplish. The panicles often remain into winter. The <a href="spikelet">spikelet</a>s are oblong or gaping. It flowers from June to September. The roots are yellow.
Two subspecies have been described:
Habitat.
"Arrhenatherum elatius" is a principal species in two UK <a href="British%20National%20Vegetation%20Classification">National Vegetation Classification</a> habitat communities: the very widespread <a href="British%20NVC%20community%20MG1">MG1 ("Arrhenatherum elatius" grassland)</a> and the much rarer <a href="British%20NVC%20community%20MG2">MG2 ("Arrhenatherum elatius" - "Filipendula ulmaria" tall-herb grassland)</a>. This means that it can be found with species such as "<a href="Dactylis%20glomerata">Dactylis glomerata</a>" (also known as cock's-foot and orchard grass), and "<a href="Filipendula%20ulmaria">Filipendula ulmaria</a>" (also known as meadow-sweet).
It is found on road verges, along hedges and riverbanks.
It can colonise and stabilise limestone scree, bare calcareous cliffs, maritime shingle and coastal dunes.
